div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7192] ALEXANDRIA, MONDAY, MAY 08, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: Orient-Pacific Line of Royal Mail Steamers.
div.p: REDUCED SUMMER FARES FROM MAY TO OCTOBER INCLUSIVE.
OUTWARDS to AUSTRALIA.
R.M.S. “Orotana" will leave Suez about May 19 | R.M.S "Orontes" will leave Suez about June 2.
HOMEWARDS to NAPLES MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY
R.M.S. "Omrah" will leave Port Said about May 10 | R.M.S. “Ophir" will leave Port Said about May 24
Egyptian Government Officials allowed a rebate of 15% off the above fares.

Return tickets no longer issued, but passengers paying full fare in one direction allowed abatement of 1/3 fare back if return voyage be within 4 months of arrival, or abatement of 20 o/o if return voyage be made within 8 months of arrival.
Agents. Cairo:—Thos. Cook & Son. Alexandria : —R. J. Moss & Co.—For all information apply
Wm. STAPLEDON & Sons, PORT-SAID & PORT-TEWFIK (Suez) 31-12-904

OUTWARDS to COLOMBO, TUTICORIN, etc., and RANGOON. Departures from Suez.
S.S. Shropshire 5,720 tons, leaves about May 11.
S.S. Straffordshire 6,000 tons, leaves about May 25.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON. Departures from Port Said.
S.S. Cheshire 6,708 tons, leaves about May 15.
S.S. Derbyshire 6,635 tons leaves about May 29,
FARES from Port Said to Marseilles £12.0.0, London £17.0.0, Colombo £32.10.0, Rangoon £37.10.0.
Agents Cairo: THOS. COOK & SON. Suez & Port Said : WM. STAPLEDON & SONS, 31-12-905

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIM direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency. 31-12-904

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Pharos now on the berth, will sail on or about Friday, May 12, to be followed by S.S. Seti.
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.

R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents. 26-12-905

BAGGAGE AND FORWARDING AGENTS.
Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.

RESIDENTS IN EGYPT proceeding to Europe for the summer are requested to apply to our offices for information respecting their Passages, where steamer plans may be consulted and Berths secured by all Lines of Steamers to all parts of the Globe; arrangements can also be made for the collection and forwarding of their baggage and clearance at port of arrival.

CIRCULAR NOTES issued payable at the current rate of exchange in all the principal cities of Europe. Cook’s Interpreters in uniform are present at the principal Railway stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their travelling tickets.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Wady-Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum. Moderate fares.
FREIGHT SERVICE, Steamers leave Cairo every Saturday and Tuesday for Assouan and Halfa.
Special Steamers and Dahabeahs for private parties.
Special arrangements for tour in PALESTINE, SYRIA and the DESERT, Lowest Rates.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste-Line.

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday a.m. in time for express to Paris, London, Rome. Arrival Trieste Wednesday noon connecting with Vienna Express (Trieste-Ostende through carriage) and expresses to Italy and Germany.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 10th and 24th May.
Far East Line.

(Departures from Suez) To Aden, Bombay, Colombo, Penang, Singapore, Hong-Kong, Shanghai, Yokohama, Kobé about July 5 and August 4. To Aden, Karachi, and Bombay accelerated service about August 18. To Aden, Karachi, Bombay, Colombo, Madras, Rangoon, and Calcutta about July 20.
East African Line.
To Aden, Mombassa, Zanzibar, Beira, Delagoa Bay, Durban, about July 4 and August 3.
Syrian-Cyprus-Caramanian Line.

La National Bank of Egypt reçoit des dépots à termes fixes, fait des avances et ouvre des comptes courants sur titres, valeurs et marchandises. Elle s’occupe de l’achat et de la vente d'effets sur l’Etranger, de l'escompte, ainsi que de toutes opérations de Banque. 31-12-904

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
Subscribed Capital £1.500,000
Paid up Capital £ 500,000
Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.head: British Chamber of Commerce.—
div.p: We would call the attention of persons interested in Egyptian trade to the work of the British Chamber of Commerce of Egypt, whose office in Alexandria gives information as to standings trade, &c., to its members, and whose monthly publication reviews our commerce. The annual subscription is 11 and all British traders should become members. Our London office, 36, New Broad- street E.C., acts as London agency to the Chamber.

V. J. FLEURENT, Cairo
F. MICALLEF, Sole Agent, 11 Bab Midan, Alexandria

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Yesterday opened with a light breeze from the N.N.E. but towards noon the wind suddenly changed to the N.N.W. The day was rather warm, but becme beautifully cool in the evening. Barometer steady.

table.head: OTHER STATIONS.
For the 24 hours ending 3 a.m. Yesterday

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber’s address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
SUBSCRIPTIONS and ADVERTISEMENTS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
London Offices : 36, New Broad-street. B.C.
THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE can be obtained in London at our office, 36, New Broad Street, E.C., and also at Messrs. May & Williams 160, Piccadilly, W.
THE “EGYPTIAN GAZETTE” IS PRINTED ON PAPER MANUFACTURED AND SUPPLIED BY THE LONDON PAPER MILLS Co., LIMITED (SALES OFFICE: 27, CANNON STREET, E.C.)

div.head: EGYPT’S ENGINEERING TRIUMPHS.
div.p: One of the most interesting sections in Lord Cromer’s Report for 1904 deals with the results of recent irrigation works, and notably of the construction of the Assiout and Assouan Reservoirs. It is difficult to avoid hyperbole in discussing these results, which have, as far as can be judged, insured the continual prosperity of Egypt for many years to come, and the Egyptian and European publics have apparently grasped the most remarkable fact connected with these and other great productive works which have been completed or commenced by the Government. Countries more happily situated than Egypt have been able to raise loans which enabled them to obtain the sums necessary for productive works intended for the benefit of posterity, and at the same time to make posterity pay in part for the blessings handed down to it. Egypt has not been in this fortunate position, haring no full financial liberty of action, and the numerous and highly remunerative works constructed have in consequence caused considerable in- convenience to the present generation of Egyptians who have paid heavily that posterity may benefit.

At the same time it is evident that the present generation will benefit to a consider- able degree from some at least of the works of public utility which have recently been completed. The Assouan and Assiout Barrages must hold a record among such works for the speed with which they have become remu nerative. They cost L.E. 3,297,000, and up to the end of 1904 a sum of L.E. 1,757,000 had been expended on subsidiary works in Middle Egypt, which enabled the best result to be obtained from the construction of the two great dams. The increased annual rental of the lands affected by the dams and sub- sidiary works is estimated at L.E. 1.553,000, their increased sale value at L.E. 16,780.000. By the end of 1908 a further million and a halt in round figures will have been spent, and the rental of these lands will have been increased by L.E. 2,687,000, their sale value by L.E. 26,570,000, and this without counting the benefits to the Delta.

This remarkable success, achieved in the teeth of constant difficulties, is probably without parallel in the history of engineering work, and Lord Cromer's tribute to the engi neers under whose auspices these great re sults have been won is right well deserved At the same time it is pleasing to know that the Egyptian Government and the great statesman to whose able guidance so much of the present prosperity of the country is due, have shown a readiness to listen to the advice of experts, and a determination to make the best use of their talents, that the Governments and statesmen of greater and more advanced nations would do well to imitate.

div.head: THE REVOLT IN YEMEN.
div.p: The announcement in this morning's tele- grams, that sixteen Redif battalions, belonging to the First Army Corps in Turkey, have been called to the colours for service in Yemen shows that the Porte is becoming alive to the gravity of the situation in Southern Arabia. The present revolt against the Sultan’s authority in these regions is, we believe, due to the chronic grievance against Turkish exactions and Corruption, which keeps rebellion simmering—when it is not actually boiling over—in that country. There seems to be grave danger that the revolt may spread north- ward from Yemen to the Hodjaz. If that were to happen, and if the Turks were to be worsted in the very cradle of Islam, the Caliph would lose his one claim to be regarded as the de facto Head of the Mohamedan world — the guardianship of the Holy Places of Mecca and Medina. That would, obviously, be an event of world-wide importance, which might have consequences of incalculable gravity.

div.head: THE WAR. JAPANESE ADVANCE. ENEMY DISPERSED.
div.p: The extreme left and right of Oyama's Army has advanced to an appreciable extant. (Hanoi.)
Tokio, May 2.

(Official). The Japanese advanced North from Tunghua, dispersed the enemy’s cavalry, and occupied Kouyatai, situated 20 miles to the north of Tanghua. They advanced on the 1st inst. towards Fen-chua from Fakuman and dispersed the enemy in the vicinities of Erhsisotun and Tashiaotun, 30 miles to the north-east of Fakuman. On the evening of the inst. the Japanese occupied Papaotun. ( Reuter.)

div.head: VLADIVOSTOK SQUADRON. RETURNS HOME
div.p: Four torpedo boats of the Vladivostok squad- appeared on the west coast of Hokkaido yesterday and burned s small sailing ship. The crew escaped but the captain was taken prisoner. (Reuter.)
Tokio, May 7.
There are no further reports regarding the Vladivostok squadron. It is believed that it returned home. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE BALTIC FLEET. RODJESTVENSKY DELAY.
div.p: The delay of Admiral Rodjestvensky is caus- ing a doubt here regarding his intention of moving northward to risk an early engagement. (Reuter.)

div.head: RUSSIAN NATIONAL ASSEMBLY. GREAT SECRET MEETING.
div.p: Despite police prohibition a great secret meeting of delegates from numerous provincial Zenstvos was held here yesterday to formulate principles for the establishment of a National Assembly. (Reuter.)

div.head: POLAND. WAITING FOR DAY OF RECKONING.
div.p: The Polish Socialist organisation has ordered strikers in Poland to return to work. It declares that they have given an impressive manifestation of unity, that the revolution is unripe, and that the workmen must patiently prepare for the final struggle for freedom. (R.)

div.head: M. DE WITTES DISFAVOR.
div.p: The Tsar has dissolved the Ministerial Com- mission on the Schools question of which M. de Witte was president. As this follows so closely the dissolution of the peasants' com- mission of whcoh M. de Witte was also presi- dent, it is interpreted as a signal mark of the disfavor into which he has fallen. (Reuter.)

div.head: WORLD-WIDE MANOEUVRES. CAUSE OF POSTPONEMENT.
div.p: Melbourne, May 6. World-wide manoeuvres have been postponed. The “Cadmus" has been ordered to join the “Clio" on the China station. Both these cruisers are generally attached to the Austra- lian squadron. (Reuter.)

London, April 6. The countermanding of the naval manaoeuvres is evoking speculation of every description, but it is generally understood that the decision is due to the continuance of the war and the apprehension of causing a delicate situation by grand manoeuvres while tire Russian and Japa- nese fleets are at sea. Moreover it would be inconvenient to deplete the China squadron at the present moment. (Reuter.)

div.head: RUSSIAN LOSSES IN OFFICERS.
div.p: St. Petersburg, May 6. The Tsar, in addressing 1,150 cadets, who were promoted officers at Tsarskoe-Selo, men- tioned that he promoted them four months earlier than usual owing to heavy losses of officers in Manchuria. (Reuter.)
St. Petersburg, May 6. The Tsar has made 1,500 cadets officers before the proper time, owing to losses in Manchuria. (Havas.)

div.head: YEMEN INSURRECTION.
div.p: Constantinople, May 7. Sixteen Redif battalions, belonging to the First Army Corps, have been called to the colours for service in the Yemen. (Reuter.)

div.head: FRANCO-ITALIAN DEMONSTRATION
div.p: Rome, May 6. The unveiling of Victor Hugo’s statue was imposing, and ended in a warm Franco Italian demonstration. (Havas.)

div.head: QUEEN ALEXANDRA IN ATHENS.
div.p: Athens, May 7. Queen Alexandra was greatly cheered at the Pan Hellenic games, at which 50,000 specta- tors were present (Havas.)

div.head: BIG PRICE FOR RACEHORSE,
div.p: London, May 6. Roberts Bass, the owner of "Sceptre,” has bought the stallion “Cyllene" for 30,000 guineas. (Reuter.)

div.head: HOME CRICKET.
div.p: London, May 6. Yorkshire beat Somerset by an innings and 224 runs. Snrrey beat Essex by 135 runs. England v. Australians drawn. (Reuter.)

div.head: The Plague
div.p: A fresh case of plague is reported from Toukh today.

div.head: Asile Rudolph
div.p: Mr. Rudolph gratefully thanks the ladies of the Rudolph Asile Guild on behalf of the poor who received clothing on Saturday, April 29.

div.head: “Mohamed. The Rise of Islam”
div.p: by Professor D. S. Margoliouth will be one of the new volumes in Messrs. Putnam’s “Heroes of the Nations!' series.

div.head: White Slave Traffic.
div.p: The first meeting of the Executive Bureau of the White Slave Traffic Repression Committee will be held at the Alexandria Gouvernment this afternoon.

div.head: Children's Ball
div.p: The annual children’s ball given by Prof. Conegliaco with the assist- ance of his pupils will take place at the Alhambra next Saturday afternoon at 3.30 o’clock.

div.head: Slavery Case.
div.p: A court martial will meet in the next few days to pronounce judgment on Gameh Abou Said, an Ababdeh, who recently abducted a Sudanese girl and tried to sell her at Om Rassin, Assonan Moudirieh.
Stray and Ownerless Dogs found in the Boulac quarter during tonight, and tomorrow at dawn, and in the Saida Zeynab quarter during tomorrow night and dawn on Wednesday, will be poisoned by the police.

div.head: The Museum Catalogue.
div.p: The catalogue of the Cairo Museum will not be completed before ten years. Eighteen volumes have already been published, seven others are in the press, and eight more are under preparation.

div.head: Suez Canal.
div.p: 19 vessels passed through the Canal on the 4th inst, 14 of which were British, 1 French, 2 German, 1 Turkish, 1 Dutch. The day's receipts were frs. 533,311.78 making the total from the 1st inst. frs- 1,479,251.79.

div.head: S. & S.F.A
div.p: -The annual meeting of the Soldiers and Sailors Families’ Association will take place at the General’s House, Moharrem Bey, at 4.30 p.m. ou Thursday, 18th inst. All who are interested in the above association are invited to attend.

div.head: Fatal Collapse of House.
div.p: A house belonging to Sheikh Ahmed El Diwani in the Haret el Geladine, Waili Kism, Cairo, collapsed on Friday. The sheikh's daughter, Mme. Zohra, was killed by the falling ruins. Her body has been recovered.

div.head: Splendid Hotels of Egypt.
div.p: The capital for the Splendid Hotels of Egypt Company, Limited, was covered forty-six times over. The mathematically equitable manner in which the shares have been allotted, as shown in the notice we published in our issue of Friday last, has given general satisfaction.

div.head: Italian School at Port Said.
div.p: The Mar- quis di Salvago-Raggi is expected to return to Cairo to-day or to-morrow from Port Said. The Italian Minister has been the guest of Count de Serionne and is said to be making arrangements for the purchase of a site for an Italian school at Port Said.

div.head: St. Georoe's Day. O. S.
div.p: A service in honor of the nameday of H.M. King George of Greece was celebrated at St. George's Church, Old Cairo, on Saturday morning. M. Gennadis, with the staff of the Greek Agency and Consulate, and many well-known Greek residents, were present at the ceremony.

div.head: Alhambra Theatre
div.p: The operatic compa- ny at the Alhambra Theatre is attracting good audiences. Yesterday’s matinee was crowded on the occasion of a repetition, of Primacera Scapigliata, when Signa Imbunbo came in for the usual ovations which that talented actress always receives. In the evening the Venditore di Uccelli was given. To-night In cerca di felicita will be given.

div.head: Lady Gorst’s Portrait.
div.p: The portrait of the wife of the late Financial Adviser by Professor Herkomer, now on exhibition at the Royal Academy, is described as "a splendid exercise in robust painting, direct, forcible, and unhesita ting, exuberant almost in its vitality and yet controlled by the surest seuse of artistic pro- priety."

div.head: Vienna Choral Society.
div.p: The net receipts obtained by the Vienna Choral Society during their recent tour in Egypt amount to P.T. 44,302. This sum has been forwarded to the Austro Hungarian Diplomatic Agent, who has divided them among various charities, as follows: Moslem charities, P.T. 6,552 ; Aus trian charities, P.T. 6,256 ; Italian charities, P.T. 3,''276 ; French charities, P.T. 1,276 ; French Orphanage, P.T. 2.000; Rudolph Home, P.T. 3,276 ; Anglo American Hospital, P.T. 7,600; Deaconesses' Hospital, P.T. 6,552; Austrian Rudolph Hospital, P.T. 7,212.

div.head: The Egyptian Press.
div.p: In regard to Yacoub Pa-ha Artin’s ecture on Egyptian Press Sta- tistics up to 1904, which is to be given at this afternoon's meeting of the Egyptian Ins- titute, it is worthy of note that, in 1840, there were only two newspapers in Egypt. One of these was published in the Turkish, and the other in the Arabic language. Both Were offi- cial. In 1868, a private French newspaper was, for the first time, published at Alexandria There are now 30 daily papers, 67 weekly or fortnightly, and 52 monthly or bi-monthly periodicals, making in all a total of 149. Of those, 96 are published in Arabic, 22 in French, 15 in Greek, 7 in Italian, 5 in English, 3 in Armenian, and 1 in Hebrew.

div.head: Merchant Seamen's Home.
div.p: A concert arranged by Mrs. Roberts was given on Friday evening last. There was a large gathering of seaman present, and Rev. H. P. Reid presided Miss MunGavin’s songs, “The River of Year” and “Faithful unto Death," showed off her fine voice to perfection, and as an encore she gave “Three fishes went sailing." Mrs. Baylis’s pretty song and the duet with Mr, Johnson from “Veronique” were enthusiastic- ally encored. Mr. Johnson also sang “The Yeomen of England” and “Gallop away” in an artistic style, and his encore "Devotion’ was splendidly given. Mr. Plank’s musical recitations, “The Lesson of the Water Mill” and “An Old Bachelor," were quite a nice change in the programme, and “Domestics’ Asides" and "Otto and the Auto" were very amusing. Mr. Heaton sang briskly “Anchored” and also accompanied some songs, as did Mrs. Roberts, who also played two lively pianoforte solos, "Autumn Pastime" and "Moore’s Irish Melodies," by A. F. Smith. She did not sing owing to a cold. Several others who were to have taken part were prevented through indis position. Among those present we noticed Mrs. A. Ward, Miss Harbord, Grafton Bey, Capt Thomas, Milburn Bey, Mrs. and Miss Milburn, and several others.

TYROL -Weissenstein Castle 3410 ft First-class private hotel near Windisch-Matrei; Station, Lienz (reached from Venice or Trieste). Good mountaineering centre. Tennis. Fishing, best June and September. Prospectuses and Pho- tographs, "Egyptian Gazette” office, Cairo. 25365 48* 40

ENGLISH PENSION, ITALIAN RIVIERA The best halfway house between Egypt and England is VIRAGO, near PISA Main line express stop. Pine woods, Sands, Sea bathing mild climate, English Pension, Villa Shelley. Every home comfort. Electric light. Modern sanitation, Sunny aspect, close to sea and gardens

div.head: BRIGANDAGE IN FAYOUM ARMED BAND ON THE PROWL. A REIGN OF TERROR.
div.p: ( From our Correspondent. )

Medinet-el-Fayoum, Saturday. Something akin to a reign of terror prevails in this province just now. The country is being overridden by a formidable band of brigands. These men, who number about a hundred, have got clever leaders and are well organised. They are armed with the best guns, and have made their head-quarters on the cultivated spots round the desert and hills that separate the Fayoum from the Beni Souef province. They have moreover got secret agents in the various villages of the province. They generally commit their depradations on dark nights, when they make organised descents on the residences of the wealthy inhabitants.

The night before last, members of the gang formed a cordon round the village of Bishoun, some of the men being stationed at each bridge and main thoroughfare to prevent help being sought by the inhabitants from the neigh- bouring villages. The omdeh of the village was besieged in his house by twenty armed men. There were only four ghaffirs in the vicinity, the others being out on duty with the molahiz of police, and these four men were utterly powerless to cope with the armed marauders.

Another cordon was formed round the resi- dence of the omdeh’s cousin, Soliman el Sayed, who is reputed to have considerable wealth at bis house. More than a hundred shots were fired by the brigands, the ghaffir of the house being killed and three servants wounded.

On their entering the house Soliman el Sayed was threatened with immediate death unless he gave up the keys of his safe. This he promptly did, and the robbers made a clean sweep of all the money and valuables they could lay their hands on, including a quantity of jewellery belonging to the omdeh’s wife and sister. They afterwards made good their escape, and are in safe hiding.

On hearing of this extraordinary occurrence, I immediately proceeded to the village of Bishoun on behalf of the "Gazette” and there found the Moudir, the Chief of the Parquet, the Commandant of Police and tho district mamour engaged in conducting an enquiry. It was a case, however, of “locking tho stable after the horse is stolen," as the robbers had left the village a long time before they arrived on the spot. I think it would have been better if the Moudir had also sent a detachment of police and ghaffirs to cut off the retreat of the band before they could get across the desert. It would likewise have been advisable to send detectives to find out where the members of the band come from, and to keep their eyes on the brigands, in order to find out what they are going to do beforehand, and not what they have already done.

div.head: PUBLIC v. PRIVATE EXECUTION
div.p: Three shocking crimes have taken place here lately, and it does not seem as if the new sys- tem of private executions is working well. Few of the criminal classes read the newspapers, and as a rule they hear nothing about the carrying out of capital sentences. Fayoum people do not see the hoisting of the black flag at the prison in Cairo, and those who read about the execution of a murderer are not the criminals who would be, perhaps, deterred from crime if they witnessed a public execution on the spot where a murder had been committed. This might act as a deterrent, which should be the main object of punishment
ENGLISH LANGUAGE IN SCHOOLS

I visited the Government school the other day, and spoke with some of the pupils, who are making very satisfactory progress in learn ing English. The headmaster graduated in England, and is therefore proficient in the language of that country. In addition to the Government school, there are three others —one for boys and two for girls—where all the pupils learn English. In a few years' time the language should become almost universal in Egypt, enabling the natives to read good English books and learn the lessons in moral ity, good behaviour, etc., that they cannot find in the Arabic books, which are so hard to understand.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. "Scottish Prince” left Antwerp on Friday last with general cargo, &e, for Malta and Alexandria. The Messageries Maritimes S.s "Senegal,” from Marseilles, passed the Straits of Messins on Saturday and is due here to-morrow. The Moss liner “Amasis” arrived at Liver- pool on Saturday morning. The Moss liner "Nitocris” arrived yesterday morning from Glasgow, via Gibraltar and Malta, with mail and general cargo. The Ellerman S.S “Sardinia" sailed on Sa- turday for Manchester with passengers and a general cargo including 4,844 bales cotton, and 10,951 bags onions.

div.head: ARISTON AERATED WATERS
div.p: Guaranteed Distilled.
ALEXANDRIA: 7 Rue de la Poste.
CAIRO opposite the Tramways Co. Works, Sharia Sahal, Kasr-el-Nil

div.head: SUCCESSFUL BIG GAME HUNT. MR. McGILLIVRAY’S RETURN.
div.p: Mr. D. P. McGillivray, of the National Bank of Egypt, returned to Cairo on Friday morning, via the White Nile and Khartoum, from his big game hunt in Abyssinia. His bag consists of a concession granted by the Emperor Menelik to the National Bank for the establishment of an International Bank of Abyssinia, and about one hundred head of big game, amongst which are some record heads. Mr. McGillivray suffored considerably towards the latter, part of his journey from inflammation of the eyes, but we are happy to hear that he is now pro- gressing towards speedy recovery. We beg to tender him our hearty congratulations at such a successful issue of his expedition, which is as largely due to his indomitable will as to his financial capacity and Skill with the rifle.

div.head: THE PILGRIMAGE.
div.p: We understand that the report of the Emir el Hag dealing with the El Hamra incident has been received at the Ministry of the Interior. Since certain other versions of the affair have been received from pilgrims who were present, it has been decided to forward their evidence with the Emir el Hag’s report to the War Office, where a committee of enquiry will shortly be convened.
TRIPOLI FRONTIER.
Lemloun Bey, who has returned from Ben- ghazi, reports that all is quiet on the Tripoli frontier, and that sheep and cattle are being collected for import Into Egyptian territory.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive is going to Wardan this after noon to inspect the progress of the Mariout line.

div.head: THE GHIRGEH SCANDAL.
div.p: A council of discipline will be held at the Ministry of Justice to try the judge of the Mehkemeh Sharieh of Tahta Markaz on Wednesday next, under the presidency of the Minister of Justice, assisted by the Grand Cadi and the Grand Mufti of Egypt.
The following are the terms of the arreté, issued by the Minister of the Interior, for the suspension of the Moudir of Ghirgeh, Hasaan Bey Wassif:-

Le Ministre de l’Intérieur, vu le rapport adressé par le Procureur général au Ministre de la justice, en date du 3 mai 1905, constatant la nécassité de mettre on mouvement l'action publique contre Hassan Wassif bey, moudir de Guirgueh, accusé avec d’autres dans une affaire de faux;
Considérant que dans ces conditions il y a lieu de suspendre le dit moudir de ses fonctions...

div.head: SUPREME CONSULAR COURT.
div.p: The Congdon-Houghton libel action has been settled out of court, the defendant having expressed regret that the article in question was published. The case was therefore dis- missed.

Mr. O’Sullivan, of the Irrigation Depart- ment, brought a case against the Delta Light Railway Company for damage done to two. horses. The action was withdrawn from the Supreme Court and will be sent before the provincial court.

div.head: STATE RAILWAY INSTITUTE.
div.p: The second annual excursion of the Egyptian State Railway Institute was held on Friday under the presidency of Mr. George Walker chairman of the institute, when some 60 mem- bers, with their wives, children, and friends availed themselves of the opportunity to pay a visit to that most favorable of all pic-nic places, the Barrage. A special train, provid- ed free by the Railway Administration, left Cairo at 9 a.m., and arrived at the Barrage shortly before a quarter to ten. Some seven hours of enjoyment were spent by the party before the return at 5.35 p.m. The manage- ment and catering were in the hands of Mr. Ben Defrece, manager of the institute and the greatest compliment we can pay him is to say that everything went off without a hitch, and that everyone agreed that a greater success could not be attained. A excellent lunch and tea were provided and all the provisions, which were brought from Cairo, were of the very best, and not even the ice-chest was forgotten. Beverages of al- most every description were provided and the bar was well patronised, for the day was some- what warm. Members and guests alike vied with each other in their efforts to make the outing a success, and it was unanimously agreed that should future excursions be run on the lines of this one, failure would be impossible.

div.head: POSTAL NOTICE.
div.p: Persons residing in the suburbs of Cairo and Alexandria, such as Helouan, Ramleh, etc., are advised to have their correspondence from abroad addressed to the town as well as the suburb, e.g., Mr. X. Y. Z., Ramleh, Egypt Alexandria.
Correspondence thus addressed proceeds di- rect to Cairo or Alexandria and can be more quickly delivered than that addressed only to the suburb, which has to be sorted at the port of entry.

div.head: THE S.S. “CANDLESHOE."
div.p: The whole of the damaged cargo is now out of this vessel. The official estimate of the loss sustained as regards cargo alone, and excluding the damage done to the ship herself which is considerable is between £18,000 and £19,000. The necessary repairs to the hull of the ship, inasmuch as they apparently do not affect her seaworthiness, are to be carried out in England. She will sail in a fortnight’s time.

div.head: NEW BRITISH TORPEDO DESTROYERS.
div.p: At dawn to-day the destroyers “Dee,” “Erne," and "Ettrick" arrived from England on their way out to Colombo. These vessels, and three others which are due to-morrow morning, the. "Arun," "Exe," and “Itchen,” are remarkable in their way, as they mark quite a new epoch in naval construction. Included in the 1903 Estimates, they are quite new, steam 25.6 knots, and having a displacement of 540 tons, appear to be an improvement on the old type Up till 1902 no destroyers afloat exceeded 280 tons; the behaviour therefore of this new class will be watched with interest.

div.head: PASSENGER LISTS. ARRIVALS.
div.p: Le paquebot "Singapore" de la Cie Florio Rubattino arrivé hier de Gènes, avait à bord:

MM. Richmann, F. Errante, N. Perecchi, Av. A. Cacace, E. S. Bender, Baron van der Berch, L. Caron, R. de Stefano, P. Agostnco, Meabe, Poppof, M. Corasson Cassilliger, Dr Budde et comp., Giglie Oberti, Don Enrico et 10 passagers de 3e classe.
Le paquebot “Cleopatra" du Lloyd Autri- trichien arrivé ce matin de Trieste avait à bord.
MM. Cremona, Zuckerbacker, Hankins, Jehle, Arsfalg, C. F. Vogel, Nieroth et sa soeur, Aristzid, Knasel, Cavalli et bébé, et 23 passa- gers de 3me classe.
DEPARTURES.
Per S.S. "Sardinia" sailed for Manchester on Saturday : Mr. Fred Rigg, Mr. J. B. Hum- phreys, Mr. Carlos Ronzevalle, Mr. C. W. Hatfield, Mr. C. Broulchurst, Mrs. C. J. Esan, Miss Alice Ironomonger.
Le paquebot "Portugal" parti vendredi pour Marseille avait à bord :—

M. Lazare Mires, Mme Satow, Mlle Aude et 2 enfants, M. Jean Multida, M. Glenat, Mme M. Mardo, Mlle Murdo, Mmes Rolland, Re- vieh et S. Denis, M. Pelissier, M. M. Kabbag, M. Schulle, M. Bancher, Capt. Hills, Capt. Brockenriger, M. Anderut, Mme Koblet, M. Boudon, Mme Blum, famille Debonne, famille Leroux, M. et Mme Croissant, Dr. Sayed, Mme Lafton, M. et Mme Tisseau, M. Tullock, M. Assimacopulo, M. Crossley, M. Walker, M. et Mme Hadjes, Mme et Mlle J. de Zogheb, M. I. Slemback, Mme Lorello, R. P. L. Perroy. M. Rossano, Mme de Lestrie, M. Morand, Mme Vve Laugier, Mme Van de- Hecht et deux enfants, Mme Vve Mahmoud Affify, M. Bouvier, M. Sambos, M. Herbonnez, Mme Molmi Belned, Mme Belingon, M. A. Collingudge, M. Batin, M. R. J. Luston, M. W. Sheldon, M. Tigueron, Mlle. Chossogniole, Mme Longworck, M. Paul Spriet, M. Saba- dini, M. et Mme Billaud, Frères Alphonse et Lambert, M. Debbas, M. Nabas, Mlle Ge- naoui, Mlle Hoss, M. S. Hoss, Mme Oubrey Mme Vexler et enfant M. Aldan, Mlle. Trouiller, M. et Mme Muste, M. Bronwig Mlle et Platt, 17 passagers de 3me classe et 29 de 4me classe.

Le paquebot "Semiramis” da Lloyd Autri- chien parti samedi pour Trieste avait à bord: M. et Mme U. Ammann et 3 enfants, M. Hugo Aucke, M. le Dr. L. Aucke, Mme Bernhard Mme Bond et Compagne, M. et Mme C. Berla et enfant M. et Mme B. Coret, Mme Dotti et fille, Mme Daendliker, M. H. et Mile El. Farnall, M. Grandy et 2 soeurs, Mme Emilie Gibbons, Mme Mathilde Gallichi, Mr. R. Gol- denberg, S.A. le Prince et la Princesse Mob. Aly Halim et 4 de famille, M. et Mme Hafner M. Hunter Jones, Just et 2 de famille, M. et Mme H. J. Lancashire, M. R. Lecomte, M. lAssak, M. Hubert Miller, Mme Mnrikch, M Meditz, M. G. Meinecke, Lord Milner, M. Oberhofer, M. le Comte A. Pongracz, M. Rossi J. Raff, Mme Aly Bey Saddick, Mme Staub Mr. E. Stangen, M. R. H. A. Storrs, Mr. Em. Stross, M. le Comte Szickeny, S. E. et Mme Serfonlah Pasha Yousry, Mlle Sibbald, Mme E. Staiger, M. B. Springer, M. Angelo Titi M. et Mme R. A. Tilche, gouvernante et 2 enfants,M. le Baron H. de Trauttenberg, M. et Mme J. J. Tschopp, M. Tolentino,M. Werner M. le Comte et la Comtesse Wedel, M. Mohed- din Bey Yousry, M. Selim Zogheb, M. Naghib Zogheb, Famille Arlich, M. Bayer, M. et Mme Cizovich et nièce, M. David Coen, Mme Du- mont, Mr. A. Dahl, M. G. Ernesti, Mme Fleischmann, Mr. Frederick, M. M. Frank M. et Mme Vve Portogaloglu, Mme Scanavi Mlle E. Seifert, Mr. W. Strimer, M. et Mme P. Stoermer,M. et Mme Kueuokeil,Mlle Oxford 10 femmes de chambre, 3 valets et 52 passa- gers de 3e classe.

div.head: WINDSOR HOTEL
div.p: Largest 1st class and most comfortable Hotel In Alexandria. Facing the sea Central position. Under English management 1 1 904 GRAND HOTEL BONNARD ALEXANDRIA PER DAY, WINE INCLUDED

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Prince Mohamed Aly Pasha, who recently arrived in Paris from Constantinople, accom- panied by Mansour Bey, his secretary, expects to remain in Paris for some weeks.
Lord Milner, Sariallah Pasha Yusri and his wife, the Princess Shukar, left Alexandria for Europe on Saturday by the Austrian Lloyd steamer.

A marriage has been arranged, and will take place in October between Major Edward Sidney Herbert, the Black Watch (attached Egyptian Army), and Gwendolen, youngest daughter of tho Right Hon. Sir John E. Gorst, M.P.

The following marriage notice appears in "The Times" of the 1st inst. "On the 26th April, at St Peterss, Cranley Gardens, S.W., by the Rev. J. G. Gauntlett, assisted by the Rev. E. Bormer Shokell, Olivet Herring, second son of the late Tomlin Campbell, Esq., of Jamaica, to Martha Marion, second daughter ot James Watts Grimes, Esq., late of Tco- woombo, Queensland.”
Lieut-Col. G. M. Mackenzie, 2nd Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, and Lieut. E. A. H. James, R.E, have been granted leave of absence on private affairs.
Mr. Landon, Inspector of Irrigation in the Indian Irrigation Service, is shortly to be appointed to the Irrigation Department for service in Lower Egypt.

Among the latest arrivals at the Eastern Exchange Hotel, Port Said, are Mr. C. E Macdonald, Mr. and Mrs. A. M. Hafner, Mr. E W. Buckley, Mr. L. A. Cooper, Mr. G. B. Goyder, Mrs. S. Gallienne, Suleiman bin Nasser, Mr. A. Eeman, Mr. F. Canevari, Mr. Ant. Dottori, Mr. J. Williams, Miss Treseder.

div.head: PUMPS IN EGYPT.
div.p: To the Editor of the Egyptian Gazette. Dear Sir,—We notice in your issue of the 3rd inst. a paragraph headed "Pumps in Egypt" referring to some observations made in “The Times" concerning the alleged superiority of Continental-made, and especially French, pumps, as compared with those of British manufacture. A correspondent writes you disputing-the accuracy of some of the statements made by “The Times” correspondent above, and has repeated the same in the paper "African Commerce".

We have had a very large experience during the last forty years in the sale of centrifugal pumps in this country. For some years we were the agents of Messrs. J. and H. Gwynne, of Hammersmith, subsequently we took up the agency of the late firm of Messrs. Gwynne and Co., Essex works, Strand, London, and we have now for many years represented Messrs. Ruston Procter and Co., Limited, of Lincoln, in the same line.

It is a fact that until lately Continental pumps have been increasingly in demand in Egypt, not on the score of price, for they are considerably dearer than British, but upon that of superior mechanical efficiency. So constantly was this brought to our notice that we induced Messrs. Boston Proctor and Co., Limited, to purchase several French pumps by the best makers and carry out a series of experiments with electric drives and measured tanks, &c., the results of which completely bore out the ver- dict of the poblic. The efficiency of some of these pumps was very good, and much in advance of what British makers are as a rule disposed to guarantee. Messrs. Ruston Proctor and Co., Limited, decided to at once re-design their pumps, combining the best points in both British and French makes, and brought out their new pattern helical pump, with which when tested in a similar manner they obtained as high an efficiency in some cases as 84%. We are prepared to guarantee in all sizes about 80% mechanical efficiency with these pumps and are glad to be able to report that all our customers who have tried them are more than satisfied.

We feel sure you will consider the above facts of interest, as it is constantly stated that British manufacturers will not move with the times, and an instance such as the above shows that however true the reproach may occasionally be it is not of universal application.—Yours obediently, for Allen Alderson &Co., Limited, F. Allen, Director. Alexandria, May 6.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Auiourt hui a midi et demie) Londres etant venu en hausse, notre marche a brillamment debute ce matin, mais il n’a pas tarde a reactionner sous le poids des realisa- tions.
Cependant, la plupart des grosses valeurs eloturent notablement an-deesus des cours de samedi.
Ainsi la National Bank monte de 27 5/8 a 27 15/16, !e Credit Foncier de 313 a 318 l’Agricole de 13 7/16 a 13 5/8 et la Daïra de 28 1/2 a 28 11/16.
Par contre, plusieurs valeurs de second ordre sont en baisse: les Markets tombent a 22/3, la Salt &Soda a 34/3, la Khedivial Mail a 4 1/2 Somme toute la tenue est ferme aveo tendance a la hausse.
Les plaidoieries du proces entre les Privili giees et lee Dividendes Tramways d’Alexandrie ont ete renvoyees au 22 mai pour attendre l’arrivee d’Angleterre d’un procès-verbal d’assemblee
